g.title: Rectangle
g.desc: Flyweight (=cache) Share objects by separating extrinsic and ...
g.text: Flyweight (=cache)Share objects by separating extrinsic and intrinsic object state to reduce memory usage.

g.title: Rectangle.119
g.desc: A ‘huge’ number of objects don’t fit in the scarce RAM
g.text: A ‘huge’ number of objects don’t fit in the scarce RAM

g.title: Folded Corner.138
g.desc: Flyweight pattern enables sharing resources to optimize RAM u...

g.text: Flyweight pattern enables sharing resources to optimize RAM usage. The flyweight pattern achieves this by extracting extrinsic objects state from intrinsic object state. Extrinsic object state is context dependent and varies per object. Intrinsic object state, is context independent. Intrinsic object state has the characteristic that it varies less than the extrinsic state. Intrinsic objects are called Flyweights. Extrinsic objects are often called Contexts. An example of the Flyweight pattern from the GOF is the Document Editor. Assume each letter in the document editor is an object that has a position and a character attribute. The character of the letter object is intrinsic, it is not context dependent, it can only be one of the 26 letters in the alphabet. However, the position of the letter object is context dependent. The letter object can locate itself all across the document. The position is extrinsic. The position attributes ‘outweigh’ the amount of possible characters. Extracting the position and instead passing it as an argument reduces RAM usage. This is because we can re-use the same character intrinsic state (=Flyweight) in combination with different position extrinsic states (=Context). I.e. memory sharing.

g.title: Folded Corner.196
g.desc: The Flyweight pattern extracts object extrinsic from object i...

g.text: The Flyweight pattern extracts object extrinsic from object intrinsic state to provide more ‘optimum’ memory usage. However, separating the intrinsic and extrinsic state of an object could violate SRP, because the operations in that object could operate on both the extrinsic and intrinsic state. This separation can introduce confusion and it will make code harder to comprehend as a ‘whole’. The code will become scattered. Code effort will also increase, because we need to assemble and reference extrinsic and extrinsic state correctly.

g.title: Folded Corner.202
g.desc: The Flyweight pattern optimizes RAM usage. However, this is a...

g.text: The Flyweight pattern optimizes RAM usage. However, this is at the expense of execution speed. The extrinsic state could be computed and Flyweights need to be looked-up. The extrinsic state is situated in the class along side the intrinsic state in case the Flyweight pattern is not applied. In this case there is no runtime ‘overhead’ because it is resolved at compile time. However, Flyweight ensures less allocation ‘calls’, which increases the performance in contrast to creating objects from ‘scratch’.

g.title: Folded Corner.205
g.desc: ‘Effectiveness’ of the Flyweight pattern is dependent on the ...

g.text: ‘Effectiveness’ of the Flyweight pattern is dependent on the following factors: 1. The amount of identical Flyweight re-use by multiple context.2. Context variation ‘outweighing’ Flyweight variation. However, this can be overruled by rule (1).3. Extrinsic state being computed and not saved.
